feed.title: NewsTracker: greece or greek
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: The Latest: French premier says Greek reform plan 'complete'
entry.summary: French Prime Minister Manuel Valls laid out his hopes for an imminent Greek bailout deal after the country's government sent "solid, serious and complete" reform proposals to creditors.

entry.title: Greek PM Tsipras seeks party backing after abrupt concessions
entry.summary: After walking into a party meeting to applause, Tsipras rallied his Syriza lawmakers to throw their weight behind the new proposals ahead of a snap vote in parliament on the negotiations, urging them to help keep Greece in the euro.

entry.title: The Latest: Hollande says Greek proposals are 'serious'
entry.summary: Greece has requested a third bailout of 53.5 billion euros ($59 billion) and seemingly caved in to a large chunk of creditor demands for a new round of austerity measures.

entry.title: Greek debt crisis: France to the rescue as Tsipras accepts austerity for relief
entry.summary: She has been forced to balance an angry German public, which sees no reason to give Greece billions of additional bailout money or to write down any more of its debt, against the danger of a Greek exit from the eurozone.

entry.title: Asia stocks gains as Greece, creditors narrow differences
entry.summary: U.S. stocks opened with big gains, bouncing back from a loss the day before, as investors hoped that last-ditch talks would produce an agreement between Greece and its creditors.

entry.title: Asia stocks gains as Greece, creditors narrow differences
entry.summary:
GREEK SAGA: Greece and its European creditors appeared to be narrowing their differences after Athens offered a raft of proposals to reduce the cost of pensions, hike taxes and cut state spending.

THE QUOTE: "Greece's proposal to its European creditors appears to significantly improve the prospects for a weekend agreement on extending further credit," said Ric Spooner, chief market analyst at CMC Markets.

He said an agreement between Greece and its creditors is still not certain but the fact that Greece has proposed a fiscal package along the lines of the one recently demanded by its European creditors is a "significant step in the direction of compromise."

entry.title: Greece proposes tax hikes, spending cuts, pension reforms
entry.summary: The Greek government is pledging to stick to primary surplus targets " meaning that the government is earning more in taxes than it is spending " of 1 percent this year, 2 percent in 2016, 3 and 3.5 percent in 2017 and 2018 respectively.

entry.title: The Latest: Greece seeks 53.5B euros in new bailout package
entry.summary: Greece is seeking 53.5 billion euros ($59 billion) as part of a new bailout package, according to draft legislation submitted to parliament early Friday.

entry.title: Greece rushes to finalize reforms and remain in euro
entry.summary: Hopes for a deal rose after Donald Tusk, who chairs the EU summits, said Greece's plan would have to be accompanied by creditors' suggestions on how to make the country's debt manageable in the longer term.

entry.title: If Greece gets easier rescue terms, other bailout states could face popular demands for same
entry.summary:
That makes the Greek debt controversy a political threat in Spain, with potential economic consequences spilling beyond the borders of the European Union's fifth-largest economy.

With that in mind, the Irish government's message to Greece is the most clear-cut of Europe's fellow bailout recipients: If you want to get out of the hole, admit you dug it yourself, stop blaming others - and do everything possible to reassure creditors you can be trusted to pay your bills.

entry.title: Easier terms for Greece could open a can of worms in Europe
entry.summary: Eurozone governments taking a tough line on Greece's demand for debt relief and easier bailout terms fear opening a can of worms.

entry.title: The Latest: EU's Tusk latest to urge some Greek debt help
entry.summary: Donald Tusk, who will chair this Sunday's meeting of European leaders, says any Greek deal has to be matched with realistic proposals from creditors over how to make the country's debts sustainable.

entry.title: The Latest: EU's Tusk latest to urge some Greek debt help
entry.summary:
Jens Weidmann said in a speech Thursday it's up to eurozone governments and Greek leaders themselves to rescue Greece.

EU Economics Commissioner Pierre Moscovici is hopeful that a new Greek bailout deal is possible, in exchange for "concrete, complete" reform proposals from Greece's government.

entry.title: Stocks rise as China rebounds, Greece works on reform plan
entry.summary: European benchmarks gained as Greece's government raced to finalize details of reforms as it seeks a third bailout from European nations.

entry.title: Greece rushing to finalize reforms and remain in euro
Greece seeks 3-year aid program, rushes to detail reforms
entry.summary:
In a formal request that was filled with vague promises but short on details, the Greek government pledged to "immediately implement a set of measures as early as the beginning of next week" - but did not specify what these were.

Speaking in Washington, Lagarde said Greece needed to continue cost-cutting reforms, but added: "The other leg is debt restructuring, which we believe is needed ... for debt sustainability."

U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew added pressure on the European lenders, arguing debt relief was needed for a deal - and describing a Greek euro-exit as a "geopolitical mistake."

"I don't think any prime minister of Greece could sell all the additional fiscal measures, plus the structural reforms that are needed without some sense of what the debt sustainability looks like," he said in Washington.

entry.title: Greece races against clock to submit reform proposal
entry.summary: Greece on Wednesday morning submitted a written request for a new support program from Europe's bailout fund, according to Michel Reijns, the spokesman for the eurozone's top official, Jeroen Dijsselbloem.

entry.title: The Latest: French central banker warns of chaos in Greece
entry.summary: Greece submitted a request for a new support program from the European Stability Mechanism Wednesday morning.

entry.title: Merkel to visit Balkans amid Greek crisis
entry.summary: EU leaders have called for a full EU summit to take place on Sunday, July 12, 2015 to continue discussion on the Greek crisis.

entry.title: Merkel to visit Balkans amid Greek crisis
entry.summary:
Angela Merkel begins a two-day tour of the Balkans on Wednesday, visiting three countries whose ambitions to join the European Union have been complicated by the Greek crisis and their mutual rivalries.

All three states have declared their desire to join the EU, but in the wake of the Greek bailout turmoil Merkel and other EU leaders are likely to be more wary of admitting countries with troubled economies.

entry.summary: "Still, for traders there are only two games in town and these remain China's equity markets and the Greek negotiations."

entry.title: China Leads Dive in Asia Stocks as Greece Rattles Investors
entry.summary: Chinese stocks led a slump in Asian markets on Wednesday as the sell-off in Shanghai intensified and Greece's future in the euro remained highly uncertain.

entry.title: Greece Gets Sunday Deadline to Stave Off Collapse

entry.title: The Latest: Dutch: Greece needs quick solution to save euro

entry.title: Exposed to Greek banks, Balkans brace for trouble
entry.summary: SLOVENIA - Although there are no Greek banks operating in Slovenia, the eurozone member is exposed to the Greek crisis through its funding of aid to Greece.

entry.title: Exposed to Greek banks, Balkans brace for trouble
entry.summary:
Millions of people in Serbia, Albania, Bulgaria, Macedonia and Romania have their deposits in Greek bank subsidiaries in their own countries, putting the Balkans on the front line in the Greek crisis.

Though Greece's limits on cash withdrawals have not extended to subsidiaries in the Balkans, the deposits could be at risk if the parent banks collapse.

Here is a look at the Balkan countries that have most at risk in Greece's crisis.

"If this crisis persists in Greece, I may consider changing the bank," said Slavica Martinovic, who keeps an account in one of the Greek banks in Belgrade.

entry.title: Exposed to Greek banks, Balkans brace for trouble
entry.summary: SERBIA - It has also limited the amount of money Greek banks can send back to their parent companies in Greece.

entry.title: Western Union restarts money transfer service in Greece
entry.summary: (Reuters) - Western Union Co said it restarted money transfer service in Greece, allowing customers in the country to receive funds from overseas.

entry.title: Greece faces last chance to stay in euro as cash runs out
entry.summary:
He did not name names but may have been referring to German finance minister Wolfgang Schaeuble, who has made no secret of his scepticism about Greece's fitness to stay in the euro and last week suggested a possible "temporary" exit.

The United States, China and Japan all called for a solution in which Greece stays in the euro zone.

entry.title: Greece races to restart talks with skeptical creditors
entry.summary: Greece's financial distress became more acute late Monday when the European Central Bank refused to increase assistance for Greek banks, which are not due to reopen until Thursday.

entry.title: Greek PM Tsipras races to restart talks after vote win

entry.title: Germany, France press Greece to make fast, credible proposals
entry.summary: After five years of economic crisis and mass unemployment, Greek electors voted 61.3 percent "No" to the bailout conditions already rejected by their government, casting Greece into uncharted territory.

entry.title: Germany, France press Greece to make fast, credible proposals
entry.summary:
U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew spoke with both Tsipras the his new finance minister and said Washington looked forward to Athens and other parties resuming conversations toward resolving the Greek situation, a Treasury spokeswoman said.

Lew voiced hope such an outcome "will allow Greece to make difficult but necessary fiscal and structural reforms, return to growth, and achieve debt sustainability within the euro zone," the Treasury statement said.

Similarly, Japan's economics minister, Akira Amari, said Greece and the European Union should work hard to strike a win-win deal that would keep Greece in the currency union.

While France and Italy have emphasized the importance of more talks, a big majority of the 19 euro zone governments favor taking a hard line with Greece, diplomats said.

entry.title: After vote win, Greece's Tsipras looks to rebuild talks
entry.summary: The losses were not as great as some had feared, however, suggesting investors think that a possible Greek exit from the euro would be manageable for the global economy, though devastating for Greece and destabilizing in Europe.

entry.title: Greek PM Tsipras hurries to restart talks with European leaders
entry.summary: "The 'no' vote in Greece's referendum on Sunday dramatically increases the risk of a slide toward a disorderly Greek exit from the eurozone," ratings agency Fitch said.

entry.title: Eurozone leaders to hold emergency summit on Greece
entry.summary:
"And that is why we are now waiting for very precise proposals from the Greek prime minister, a programme that will allow Greece to return to prosperity," said Merkel, adding that eurozone countries had already shown "a lot of solidarity with Greece".

"In this context, the Governing Council decided today to adjust the haircuts on collateral accepted by the Bank of Greece for ELA," the statement said, a move that will make it more difficult to access ELA funds in the future.

Greece last week defaulted on a 1.5 billion euro repayment to the International Monetary Fund but Lagarde said her organisation was "ready to assist Greece if requested to do so".

Tsipras, 40, insists that instead of Grexit, the creditors will now finally have to talk about restructuring Greece's massive 240 billion euro ($267 billion) debt.

entry.title: Germany, France press Greece to make fast, credible proposals
entry.summary: Hollande said, "It's now up to the government of Alexis Tsipras to offer serious, credible proposals so that this can be turned into a program which gives a long-term perspective, because Greece needs a long-term perspective in the euro zone with stable rules, as the euro zone itself does."

However central bankers warned before the vote that a 'No' would make it almost impossible for the ECB to turn on the taps, leaving the Greek financial system without funds and facing imminent collapse.

Greek foreign minister visits Israel amid crisis at home

entry.title: The Latest: Much unanswered in wordy Greek ballot question
entry.summary: Instead, they argue voting "yes" will allow Greece to get a new bailout deal quickly to shore up the economy.

entry.title: 2 choices, many possible results for Greece's landmark vote
entry.summary:
LONDON (AP) - The Greek people are voting on a future in which they face two painful prospects: the slow grind of years more of austerity cuts or the country's potentially catastrophic exit from the 19-nation eurozone.

Proponents of a "yes" vote, including a parade of former prime ministers and the main opposition party, say backing the government will jeopardize Greece's place in the euro.

Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis has said he'll resign in the event of a "yes" vote and Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has hinted as much.

Despite the Greek government's assertion that a "no" vote will not lead to a euro exit, most people agree it would open up more uncertain outcomes, especially if the ECB halts its life-support measures to Greece's banks.

entry.title: Greece votes in referendum with future in euro in doubt
entry.summary:
He is urging a resounding 'No', saying it would give him a strengthened mandate to return to negotiations and demand a better deal, including a writedown on Greece's massive debt.

Called at eight days' notice, the referendum offers Greece a 'Yes' or 'No' vote on a proposal that is no longer on the table.

Anxious Greeks rallying for a 'Yes' vote also say Greece has been handed a raw deal but that the alternative, a collapse of the banks and a return of the old drachma currency, would be far worse.

entry.title: A Family Divided: Emotions Run High Ahead of Greek Vote
entry.summary: Meet the Danikoglous, an intense, articulate Greek family divided over whether or not the country should accept conditions by creditors attached to loans it needs to avoid default and a banking collapse.

entry.title: Polls open in historic Greek bailout referendum
entry.summary: Referendum campaign posters that reads "No" and "Yes" in Greek in Athens, Greece.

entry.title: Greece votes on high-stakes bailout referendum
entry.summary: A banner reading ''NO for democracy and for dignity'' referring to the upcoming referendum is placed outside a Greek Orthodox church at Monastiraki square in central Athens, Saturday, July 4, 2015.

entry.title: Greece votes on high-stakes bailout referendum
entry.summary:
In case of a "no" win, Kalyvas said the Greek government could be confronted with the refusal of other eurozone countries to negotiate a better deal because of their distrust of Tsipras.

With speculation swirling on the referendum's impact on Tsipras' government, Greece's Deputy Prime Minister Yiannis Dragasakis denied media reports that he would accept to lead a new "grand coalition" government.

entry.title: A family divided: Emotions run high ahead of Greek vote
entry.summary: "I'm afraid for my future. I see people fired every day. I worry because I see people starving outside on the road. It's scary. All my classmates from high school have left for England or America. Nobody stays in Greece. But we are Greek, we should stay. But how can I say I will find a job?"

entry.title: A family divided: Emotions run high ahead of Greek vote
entry.summary:
And they share a sense that Greece, so rich with history and culture, has fallen tragically short of its potential.

Dimitris is voting "yes" because he fears Greece would be in danger if it leaves the European Union.

His daughter Alexandra is voting "no" because she is tired of richer European nations bossing Greece around.

His son, Nikolas, is on his side - and he thinks polarized Greece may be on the verge of a civil war - while his wife Dimitra distrusts both the Yes and the No campaigns and doesn't plan to vote in Sunday's momentous Greek referendum.

The ballot question does not address whether Greece should abandon the euro currency or leave the 28-member European Union, but many voters believe those issues are at stake.

"I am forced to vote for 'yes' because I want to stay in the eurozone and the EU. I can't imagine Greece out of Europe and I don't believe that if we say 'no' we can stay. I can't take that risk. We are under the protective umbrella of the EU, a big protective social system, and we need protection. And we have to stay for political and economic reasons."

entry.title: Flawed bailouts, political missteps brought Greece to brink
entry.summary:
FRANKFURT, Germany (AP) " After two bailouts totaling 240 billion euros ($266 billion) and six years of depression, spending cuts and lost jobs, Greece teeters on the edge of collapse.

Despite its rickety finances, Greece shaped up a little for a few years and qualified to join the single currency in 2001.

Greece was waved in, and promptly went back to its old ways.

entry.title: Finance minister: Europe can't afford to let Greece go under
entry.summary: "As much for Greece as for Europe, I'm sure," Varoufakis told the Spanish newspaper El Mundo.

entry.title: Campaigns halt ahead of Greek referendum
entry.summary: Greece has braced itself ahead of a make-or-break bailout referendum as polls show the 'Yes' and 'No' camps neck and neck and uncertainty rose over the future of the country's battered economy.

entry.title: Analysts: Greek government's post-referendum future unsure
entry.summary:
That may not be the case, analysts say, since a "no" vote could still plunge Tsipras' position into uncertainty if negotiations drag on with lenders who see such the outcome as a Greek snub of the euro.

But months of talks without real results have eroded the Greek government's credibility in the eyes of Europe's power circles.

entry.title: Analysts: Greek government's post-referendum future unsure
Analysts say Greek government's hold on power uncertain, regardless of referendum outcome
entry.summary: "This government doesn't trust the institutions of the EU and the IMF, and those institutions trust the Greek government even less," said Sotiropoulos.

entry.title: Campaigns halt ahead of Greek referendum
entry.summary: They also showed an overwhelming majority of people - about 75 per cent - want Greece to remain in the euro currency.

entry.title: What happens if Greece leaves the euro?
entry.summary:
For Greece, the short-term pain and turmoil could be extreme whereas the currency union would likely survive the initial shock.

Ironically, a few experts think one of the most devastating outcomes for the euro would be if Greece leaves and, against all expectation, thrives.

A "no" could mean no more loans, leaving Greece little choice but to print its own currency after running out of euros needed to pay government wages and pension and to refloat troubled banks.

There's a widespread view among analysts that the eurozone would not collapse in the short term if Greece left.

For the long term, a Greek exit would disrupt the euro's "Hotel California" principle: that, as the Eagles put it, you can "check out any time you like, but you can never leave."

There's little doubt that leaving the euro means imminent disaster for Greece.

But that might prove more difficult if Greece was no longer a part of the euro - and did not face external pressure from fellow eurozone states to modernize its economy.

entry.title: Up-front losses would be large for Greece, long-term consequences uncertain for Europe
entry.summary:
What would that mean for the Greek people and for the European Union's 16-year-old shared currency - the crown jewel of a six-decade-old project in binding Europe's countries closer together?

Since the Greek crisis started in 2009, the governments that use the euro have come up with crisis backstops.

In a story July 2 about the Greek referendum, The Associated Press reported erroneously that the International Monetary Fund had said Greece would need debt relief worth 50 billion euros.

A strong "No" vote, he argued, would help Greece win a new deal with the eurozone's rescue mechanism that would include terms to make the country's 320 billion euro national debt sustainable.

entry.title: Greek villagers secret weapon: Grow your own food
entry.summary:
KARITAINA, Greece (AP) " Ilias Mathes has protection against bank closures, capital controls and the slashing of his pension: 10 goats, some hens and a vegetable patch.

If Greece's financial crisis deepens, as many believe it must, he can feed his children and grandchildren with the bounty of the land in this proud village high in the mountains of the Arcadia Peloponnese.

They will need to draw on them deeply, as Greece's current problems are unlikely to go away soon " whatever the outcome of the referendum Sunday on whether to accept the latest bailout proposals, which call for more austerity cuts to already razor-thin public services.

entry.title: Poll Shows Even Split Ahead of Greek Referendum
entry.summary:
(ATHENS, Greece) -The brief but intense campaign in Greece's critical bailout referendum ends Friday, with simultaneous rallies in Athens for "Yes" and "No" supporters in what an opinion poll shows will be a very close race.

The vote is set to be one of the most important in Greece's modern history, but many voters are confused about what's at stake.

entry.title: Home countrys debt crisis leaves Greek couple penniless on American honeymoon
entry.summary:
Reverend Father Vasilios Louros of St. Demetrios, which helped a Greek couple left penniless in New York City on their honeymoon thanks to the Greek financial crisis.

Strangers from two Greek Orthodox churches in the city's Queens borough came to the rescue, giving them survival cash until their flight home to Greece on Friday.

Two Greek banks issued them cards before the trip - a Visa credit card and a debit card.

On Tuesday, in despair, they reached out to the New York-based Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America, which contacted the churches in Queens' Astoria neighborhood.

In addition, an undisclosed amount came from a New York-based Greek journalist who hails from Volos.

Greece is seeking a third bailout from the eurozone rescue fund after the previous deal expired this week without agreement on the terms of final pay outs.

entry.title: Greece asks for another bailout, but Angela Merkel says no deals before referendum
entry.summary:
If no agreement is reached, Greece will default on a loan to the International Monetary Fund, setting it potentially on a path out of the euro with unforeseeable consequences for both the EU's grand currency project and the global economy.

The growing risk of Athens being forced out of the single currency brought into sharp focus the chaos likely to be unleashed in Greece and the risks to the stability of the euro.

"What would happen if Greece came out of the euro? There would be a negative message that euro membership is reversible," said Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy, who a week ago declared that he did not fear contagion from Greece.

entry.summary:
More than 13,000 people gathered in Athens to support him and denounce Greece's creditors, as they chanted: "Take the bailout and go!"

Demonstrators holding letters to form a banner take part in a protest against the European Central Bank, in Trafalgar Square, London, over Greece's debt repayments, Monday June 29, 2015.

entry.title: Greece: What tourists need to know
Asia stocks bounce back but Greece uncertainty still looms
entry.summary:
"Most traders are well prepped over the possible fallout of Greece. It's guessing which card will fall next that's the difficult bit," said Nicholas Teo, analyst at CMC Markets in Singapore.

"The Brazilian real was knocked back hard these past days as have the Turkish lira and most other emerging Asian currencies. These associations are made to Greece as they fall under the labeling of global emerging markets."

entry.title: Asia stocks bounce back but Greece uncertainty still looms
entry.summary: If Greece defaults and switches to a new currency, it's sure to shake global financial markets.

entry.title: Asia stocks bounce back but Greece uncertainty still looms
entry.summary:
Asian stock markets bounced back Tuesday, recouping some of the previous day's sharp losses, but investors remained worried the crisis in Greece could spread to other financially weak countries.

Investors were concerned that the crisis in Greece could spread to other euro countries that are struggling with high debt and austerity policies or to developing nations in Asia and South America.

entry.title: The next act: what happens now in Greece's drama
entry.summary: Greece has entered the twilight zone.

entry.title: Chobani selected as Greek yogurt provider for school lunches
entry.summary: Public schools across America will soon offer Greek yogurt as a meat substitute in school lunches beginning this fall.

entry.title: Chobani selected as Greek yogurt provider for school lunches
entry.summary:
Chobani was selected as the exclusive provider after it successfully led a Greek yogurt pilot program over the past year, expanding the program from four to 12 states.

During the first three months of the pilot program, schools in Idaho, New York, Arizona and Tennessee consumed 200,000 pounds of Chobani Greek yogurt.

entry.title: Chobani selected as Greek yogurt provider for school lunches
entry.summary: Chobani, a manufacturer of Greek yogurt, officials announced Monday, June 29, 2015, it had been selected by the U.S. Department of Agriculture to supply the yogurt as part of the federal school lunch program.

entry.title: Greece imposes capital controls, banks to remain shut

The Greek vote next Sunday on approving creditors' demands for Greece will be the country's first referendum in 41 years - and the logistics of it are daunting.

entry.title: No deal for Greece, creditors; top-level talks resume Saturday

entry.title: No deal for Greece, creditors; top-level talks resume Saturday

German Chancellor Angela Merkel, whose country is Greece's biggest creditor, said the next meeting of Eurogroup ministers on Saturday would be "of decisive importance" for a Greek solution since time was running out.

"The door is still open for the Greek side to come with new proposals or accept what is on the table," Eurogroup chairman Jeroen Dijsselbloem told reporters before briefing European Union leaders, meeting at a summit next door, on the impasse.

ATHENS, Greece (AP) - Greece has adopted legislation granting nationality to the children of foreign nationals living in the country, provided they attend or have attended school in the country.

entry.title: Greece says it will never accept wage, pension cuts
entry.summary:
ATHENS, Greece (AP) - Greece will never accept cuts in pensions and wages or extra taxes on necessities such as electricity, a government official says.

"These measures concern the popular classes and employees," said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity because of the ongoing talks in Brussels between Greece and its creditors.

entry.title: Greece PM: Will reject any deal without debt relief

entry.title: Faeroe Islands beat Greece again in Euro 2016 qualifying
entry.summary: FRANKFURT, Germany (AP) " The Faeroe Islands proved the first time wasn't a fluke when it beat Greece again 2-1 in European Championship qualifying on Saturday.

entry.title: Faeroe Islands stun Greece again to claim 2nd qualifying win
entry.summary:
The Faeroe Islands claimed a second surprise victory over 2004 European champion Greece in qualifying for the 2016 tournament on Saturday as Group F pacesetters Romania and Northern Ireland drew 0-0.

Greece, the world's 25th-best team according to FIFA, remained last in the group after being beaten 2-1 by the 102nd-ranked Faeroe Islands.

Greece's soccer slump comes as the country's government comes under intense pressure from creditors amid bankruptcy fears.

The Faeroes - with a population of around 50,000 compared with Greece's 11 million - have never even qualified for a major tournament.

Greece's 1-0 loss at home to the Faeroes in November led to coach Claudio Ranieri being replaced by Sergio Markarian.
